Student at Work in European Enterprises through Training 2016

Novara area, although strategically located at the centre of a system of traffic of people and goods from the Mediterranean to northern Europe, is currently undergoing a situation of economic decline that always strikes hardest at young people who need to be adequately prepared to meet the needs of "opening "imposed by the market and by internationalization. According to ISTAT (2015) compared to a population of 319,000 working-age people, in Novara area the employment rate is 60.9%, far from the desired EU 75%. Unemployment is 11.3% (EU average 10.8% Central Europe 7%) with a significant increase in the nr of families in need and in the brain drain (SWOT Analysis Directorate Territory Province).In order to contribute to economic and social recovery of its territory, the CSCI has been developing for a long time a strategy of internationalization among whose objectives the following are of particular importance- Consorted High School students professionalization - the strengthening of a European dimension in the education and vocational training of Novara areaIt therefore intends to act as much on students, by encouraging them to complement and enhance the skills acquired at school/ training , working closely with not Italian European companies,  as on teachers and school staff,  by encouraging them to undertake job shadowing mobility experiences at other European non-Italian facilities in order to  learn those good methodological-didactic,  substantive and organizational practices that would strengthen local training plans.For this reason "SWEET2016", by introducing important changes, will enhance even more the experience:1) of the students - starting from the " individual in-construction skills dossier", during the follow up the boys will be led to assume a professional customized project, adapting work goals to their real abilities and aspirations and basing it on the experience gained in mobility2) of the teachers/school staff - in addition to the report on the carried out experience, the "star of mobility" will be supported in the  organization of a workshop to share   with his/her colleagues acquired motivations, experiences, good practices and to agree solutions that will be  included in the POF in order to strengthen teaching, coaching, guidance and expansion of the training offer.In 2016/2017 school year, "SWEET2016" promotes:- 80 * 5 weeks mobility placements, aimed at students of the fourth year (it will favour those that without such support would never have the opportunity to live this experience)in combination with teachers- 10 * 2 weeks job shadowing mobilities for teachers (priority will be given to CLIL teachers) or school staff of  the 13 Technical/Vocational Institutes and vocational lyceums in Novara area which are CSCI members. The mobility, which will take place through an agreement with nr. 10 organisms located in UK, ES, FR, DE, IE, MT, will be validated on the basis of ECVET criteria and will be organized, in the logic of EQAVET quality, as per plan presented to obtain the Mobility CardThe activities, divided into months and detailed in the plan, are:1-2: Start Up - Finding a tutor and mentor in Italy and abroad; Coordination Committee Constitution; agreement definition with the partnership3-5: Selection of candidates - Information activities on the project; selection (written and oral) and validation activities (ranking system by defining the beneficiaries of the grants and possible reserves); Match between selected candidates and destinations6-8: Preparation of participants (orientation, soft skills and language strenghtening); Accommodation and companies/identifiedschools confirmation; transfers organization; MOU and LA signing9: Departure of candidates and internships start (work placements, tutoring and mentoring)10-12: Placement end (compilation and reporting back), meetings with the participants (follow-up), validation of acquired skills.1-12: Organization, coordination and management1-12: Monitoring and Evaluation of the project activities1-12: DisseminationCheck project 11.01.2016; Duration: 12 months.N. 8 escorts are expected, one for each group of students from Italy with minors, VISA or need to change the means of transport during the journey.The activity will last 7 days (5 on-site and 2 travelling) during which accommodation of the participants and their inclusion in the context will be checked.It is assumed that thanks to the assistance received on the first part of the journey and to the skills acquired through mobility the students will be able to travel alone on their return journey. In case of necessity and of underage students CSCI will organize (on its own resources) an “accompaniment” service during the return journey.
Non-formal And Informal Learning and International Training IN EUROPE

The project called “Non-formal And Informal Learning and International Training IN EUROPE”- NAIL IT IN EUROPE offers 105 students the possibility of a training experience abroad and it counts on the collaboration between IIS Scalcerle and bodies such as Xena (for the monitoring of competences), the town and province administrations of Padova and Fòrema Confindustria (for the training of the applicants concerning entrepreneurship and the soft skills useful in the job market and for the project dissemination in the local socio-economical and manufacturing context).The foreign partners are 27 in 9 different European countries. With some of them there is reciprocity both in the Mobility program and in other LLP and Erasmus+ programs.The foreign network includes various work and/or training organizations: companies, chemical labs, public bodies, training bodies, universities, museums, hotels and others in the tourist, cultural and commercial fields.The new professions will require updated digital skills, entrepreneurship and a sense of initiative; many of the key competences for an active citizenship can be found among the objectives of NAIL IT IN EUROPE.Our ambitious aim is to highlight and promote the development of creativity and problem-solving skills in the working and entrepreneurial fields. These are soft skills that are developed also through non-formal and informal learning, which is particularly significant in the context of a work placement experience abroad managed autonomously in many ways by the beneficiaries.  On a European level, this aim cannot be reached without competence in foreign languages and a deeper awareness of European citizenship.The work placement experience is only one step along this process of growth and awareness and it needs coordinated and solid planning and implementation of preparatory activities that invade the sphere of traditional teaching and modify contents and methodology of the students’ curricula.The beneficiaries of the NAIL IT IN EUROPE project are 105 students of IIS Scalcerle and other schools of the province, selected according to shared criteria which are described in the quality procedures of the school. They are trainees at their initial training stage who will get a High School or Technical School Diploma corresponding to level 4 of EQF. They have concluded the 4th year of their educational training (either the Foreign Languages course or the Chemistry, Materials and Biotechnologies technical course). Immigrant students and an elevated percentage of women are involved. The work placements will last from 2 to 4 weeks.The work placements abroad will be organized, monitored and assessed mainly by using ECVET criteria and will be meant to allow the acquisition of competencies that can be built up in time and acknowledged at a national and an international level in different contexts. With NAIL IT IN EUROPE,  Learning Outcomes and ECVET will be developed further. The content and the quality of the LO and the training objectives will be agreed upon by using tools such as the MoU and LA both with traditional CREDCHEM partners and with partners of other fields.The impact on the school and the staff that manages the project is considerable. More and more teachers have felt the need to be more informed and up to date on the topic in order to support their students more effectively in this experience. The comparison with other educational systems generates an effective cooperation also in the different subject departments, where learning objectives and curricula are updated. In a peer-education context, former trainees are involved to train the new applicants, to act as tutors and to be part of a working team that analyses the fallout and effects of the mobility experience on the future professional or educational life of the students. Besides the focus on soft skills, the project pursues the achievement of the following technical and professional skills in different fields:Chemical-biological:Learning methodologies and procedures in the fields of chemical, biological, biotechnological, environmental and sanitary analysis; interpreting results, writing reports; using instruments; performing a qualitative-quantitative analysis with different methods.Foreign languages, tourism:Developing multi-lingual communicative skills in the tourist, art and culture fields in hotels, tourist offices, libraries, leisure and cultural centres, universities, museums; helping in the organization of events promoting the cultural heritage of an area or exhibitions; planning itineraries; managing reservations and quotes.Child-care and educational services:Developing communicative skills which are not only multi-lingual but also focused on the beneficiary (nursery school children, young people in leisure centres); collaborating in an educational team; planning activities in consideration of the attention span and level of involvement of very young beneficiaries.
Sportello Europa: la Mobilità Transnazionale per l'Internazionalizzazione delle Competenze

The Sportello Europa project aims to pursue  Scuola Centrale Formazione’s internationalization strategic objectives through the realization of 300 transnational mobilities as follows: - 250 addressed to VET learners;- 50 transnational mobilities addressed to VET Staff.The beneficiaries of this initiative (VET learners and staff) come from the SCF’s associated vocational training centres (SCF has a network of vocational training centres in 10 Italian regions, meaning 43 associated for a total of 100 vocational centres);The project participants are:- young people coming from the regional 3year/4 year VET, focusing on those from the 2nd, the 3rd and the 4th year (these students are accompanied by didactic tutors  who monitor the on-going of the mobility experience from the management and the pedagogical point of view).- Young people coming from the training paths, already qualified with a three year VET or with a diploma (4 year VET) since no more than one year;VET staff (educators, teachers, tutors, counselors, skills assessment experts) involved in accompanying activities, job coaching, work orientation services, work based learning, social economy, social and occupational inclusion.The Istat study “Noi Italia” made in 2014, underlines that in Italy, youth unemployment (young people aged between 15 and 34 years) is of 26% and the NEET unemployment (young people between 15 and 29 years old) is of 40%.Sportello Europa, for the biennium 2016 – 2018, aims to pursue the following objectives:- To favour young people’s transition processes in the labour market;- To favour young people’s reinsertion processes in the education paths;- To promote trainers’ professional updating to favour change processes and methodological transfers in the related labour contexts;- To promote among the trainers an intercultural education approach on the basis of the huge number of foreign students and immigrants attending the SCF associated vocational training centres.The project aims to realize young people’s mobilities from 2 to 4 weeks in 6 different European countries (Spain, Ireland, United Kingdom, Germany and Finland) for the following professional sectors: Restaurant/Catering (Kitchen, dining hall, café), wellness (hairdressing salon, aesthetics), graphic, thermohydraulics, mechanics, electricity, business and administration, retail.For the trainers’ mobilities, the main themes are: work services and work based learning (following the  Riga Conclusions, CE June 2015). For the operators’ mobilities there are two competence areas:- Youth Area about pedagogic methodologies applicable to the inclusion of young immigrants (unaccompanied minors), NEET, young people at risk of scholastic dispersion and with physical and psychological disadvantage;- Adult Area about pedagogic methodologies applicable to immigrants, disables, new poverties and prisoners.The Trainers' mobilities have a length of 2/3 days (travel excluded) in 5 different European countries: Spain, France, Germany, United Kingdom, Finland and Belgium.On the basis of the internationalization strategy of the operators' competences, the project foresees 4 mobility paths of 12 days in Ireland for the foreign language preparation, addressed to educators of the linguistic/communication area, to be realised during a professional updating about foreign languages didactic and the ICT in the didactic.SCF intends to develop a training services catalogue for youth's sustainable transnational mobility promoting awareness among the operators coming from both sending and hosting context in terms of: - Choice of the mobility destination country on the basis of the sector and companies’ excellences able to host internships and to guarantee pedagogic quality;- Choice of the mobility duration on the basis of the nature of the training project decided by the sending organization for its beneficiaries (enhancing of the acquired competences, learning experience internship with an intercultural approach; internship integrated to formal learning path, internship like work experience added to the learning path or post-qualification);- Choice of the Learning outcomes to be acquired during the mobility through “soft” valorisation (reuse of the knowledge and skills  acquired abroad, transfer peer to peer) or use of recognition procedures structured through the tools collection, Gores evaluation and recognition.For the Staff mobility, SCF intends to invest on WBL methodologies on the basis of:- The promotion on an international dimension of the training company and its impact in terms of social innovation;- SCF coordination of the dual system experimentation in Italy to be realised by the associated organizations in different regions.

Most of the 90 learners’ mobilities -of 5 weeks each- expected for this ERASMUS+ Call, will be carried out at the end of August 2016; the remaining ones will be realised within May 2017. The participants will have finished, or will be next to finish the fourth year of study. Abroad, the program includes a week of preparation and 4 full-time internship in company. Although mobility is recognised as school-work alternance to all intents and purposes, its duration cannot fully overlap school lessons.  For this reason it can take place with only partial overlapping at the beginning or at the end of the school year, as in the past.  The participants come from different schools where they study technical subjects (Agriculture; Computer Sciences), Economics (Administration, in a Marketing framework; Tourism) and Vocational subjects (Wine and Food and Hospitality services, Rural Development Services). The foreign partners and destinations for this first year of the project with the Erasmus+ Charter have been identified on the basis of past experience, taking into account participants’ needs, the educational opportunities they can offer and their relevance for the project subjects: UK (Reading, Cardiff, Plymouth), France (Nice), Spain (Valencia), and Austria (Vienna).  These are destinations where the management and promotion of tourism and the valorisation of resources are supported by digital technology (typical agricultural products or their transformation, but also cultural and landscape resources). Mobility will be very important for the young participants in an economic context where exports of quality products are particularly significant and at the same time the foreign tourist trade has a relevant market share.  It will assist learning in new contexts different from those of a school laboratory or local enterprise for the development of language skills and to experiment work environments that employ different technologies and job organizations and have different missions.  The experience will make it possible to develop both specific professional and transversal competences: the business environments will stimulate reflection, curiosity and a desire to learn; to promote and increase adaptability and flexibility, autonomy and the ability to work in a team.  Experience in an unknown international context will also be a wonderful opportunity to develop relationship skills, intercultural open-mindedness and personal responsibility, all characteristics necessary to work in the local economy.As at the end of the fourth form many participants are still minors, schools consider it necessary to have them accompanied by a teacher who will act as facilitator and take care of the participants and their safety.All institutes will take part in STAFF mobility.  The six participants involved will be five teachers of CLIL subjects in the English language (computer sciences, wine and food, maths and physics, etc.) and the administrative assistant of the Cerletti Institute dealing with the project.  Mobility will take place in the first two weeks of September, as per the plan and method indicated in the project (language training and job shadowing), only in the UK for this first year.The mobility come within the international development plan of the individual schools in the consortium which in school year 2016-17 will not only participate in staff mobility but will also extend their initiatives to promoting language certification for levels B1 to C1 in the different languages studied in the schools, increasing the number by at least 10%, and applying B1 certification to the third form so as to give participants in the future 2017 mobility an advantage.  All the schools also intend to take part in the FSE and PON regional competitions for language studies abroad for the purpose of achieving certification.The schools will extend their initiatives of hospitality, referral and exchange of both students and teachers (partnerships in Key Action 2 projects in progress, bilateral relationships with schools, invitations to visiting professors and intercultural activities).  In the framework of alternating school-work, the institutes wish to provide a broader horizon in terms of links to the world of work through category associations and internationalised businesses, with lectures in the original language by experts in subjects relating to internationalisation and pertinent to the different studies.  The school that have obtained financing from PON FESR “Learning Environments” will boost their digital abilities, which will assist contacts also in international relationships

Allvar Gullstrand upper secondary school has vocational/general education in Landskrona, Sweden. Together with some local vocational upper secondary schools we constitute Technic College Western Scania.We have offered our vocational students placement periods abroad since 2006. Our two first Leonardo applications “Expanding Horizons” 2006:1002 and Exploring Horizons” 2008:529 encompassed only the tech programme at Allvar Gullstrand. The certified project “Experiencing Horizons 2010 – 2014 (LLP-LdV-MC-10/S/689) included three schools, later merged into two . When we applied for VET Learner Mobility 2014-KA102-000277, we involved one more school and established a consortium. Through the consortium we instituted a placement network for schools in Landskrona/Svalöv, also envisioned in the certification application 2010. We have during these years enlarged the number of partners abroad. The school in Svalöv did not fulfill the criteria for the VET Mobility Charter application 2015 but the second school in the consortium is expected during spring 2016 due to reorganizations, to merge into the school management district of Allvar Gullstrand, the reason for why we from now on will work with this extended school management district, in tot. 7 vocational programs. Allvar Gullstrand works with an internationalization strategy with clear mobility goals with the help of a “School ambassador for EU”, educated autumn 2011. These goals are included in the general quality evaluation/development plan of the school.It is important for the students to see more of the outside world to create user friendly and competitive products and services and to attune their professional skills and experiences to European demands and values. We want to increase their innovation abilities, strengthen their vocational qualifications and their employability in Europe where competition no longer has geographical, cultural and linguistic borders. We want to give the students more self-confidence contributing to their personal development. Through the placement abroad we try to expand/extend the horizons for them to explore/ experience and give them an international perspective for their future. The professional world is international and by working at companies abroad during the last placement period with succeeding feedback, discussions, validations (ECVET, Europass) and dissemination at home the students develop their quality awareness, their creativity and their entrepreneurship at the same time as we fortify the European idea. Europe is their future labour market! We want to emphasize the importance of languages skills in Europe with extended contacts across the borders and for future employers. Some students suffer from ADHD/ADD/other psychological disorders, which demand an adult there at the beginning of the placement.The experiences the students bring home affect the modeling of future education and placement periods at local level. Their international perspective is a welcome contribution for future employment in local companies or elsewhere enlarging the competitiveness of Swedish enterprise. Landskrona has a high youth unemployment percentage and also many immigrants of second/third generations. This project tries to offer a way to diminish youth unemployment and enhance the knowledge of EU and what EU has to offer youths in Landskrona. It is important that we can keep the education quality on a high level, counteract the segregation between natives and immigrants, offer a future without unemployment and work against the school dropout rate and the movement of students to the nearby big cities. In small municipalities we must keep school quality on a high level to survive sinking amounts of students. The quest for further education among the staff was long weak but a visit to Brussels/EU institutions in June 2015 expanded the horizons. We hope to start a three-year Nordplusspråk project autumn 2016 for vernacular teachers in the Nordic countries SE/DK/NO. We also want to intensify the benchmarking project COLLEAGUE, included in our internationalization strategy, focusing on pedagogical further training for our staff through job shadowing at successful schools abroad. Because of this we enlarge the amount of foreign partner schools for vocational education or mixed vocational/general in the south, at three schools in ES, one in IT and two in HR. Teachers are expected to increase the education quality through feedback, validation (ECVET, Europass), dissemination among colleagues. Through job shadowing the staff has the possibility to see and experience other pedagogics at the same time as they develop their quality awareness, their creativity and get a consolidated feeling for the European idea by studies/experience of modern use of ICT, multicultural classrooms, school dropout rate, EU for youths/as future labour market and an international standard in vocational education. For the moment we do need further education!

2015-1-FI01-KA109-009133 (Promo 7) is a multidisciplinary, accredited mobility project coordinated by Jyväskylä College for the VET colleges in Jyväskylä Educational Consortium. The beneficiaries are 98 students and 26 staff members of The Jyväskylä Educational Consortium including Jyväskylä and Jämsä Colleges as well as the Jyväskylä Adult Education Institute. The mobilities will be carried out over the course of one academic year 2016/2017 to 15 member states.

With the GPS4 mobility project, EPCior aims to cement its internationalization strategy, seeking to achieve the goals it has set, namely  the enrichment of the professional resume of the participants, the acquisition of soft skills, the development of language skills and the increasing awareness of European citizenship, as well as a greater the motivation among students and professionals involved.Having set as a medium term goal that all students throughout the 3-year training course shall have the opportunity to participate in at least a mobility experience and that the Staff could participate every 2 years in international activities, this application will allow our school to go further with European actions and to enrich the partnerships established.The A1 activity will include 25 students from the 12th grade (5 per class) who will participate in a 55-day mobility with partner organizations based in Spain, Romania, Italy and Poland, in the same period in which their classmates will perform their practical training in companies in Portugal. For this activity the school kept the partners for the students ‘trainings from the Renewable Energy courses, Automobile Mechatronics and Socio and cultural Animation and sought a new partner for the course of Metalworking Production, as it is the 1st time we will have trainings in this area. For each gflow, we included an accompanying teacher, who will stay with the students during the 1st week and help them to integrate in the companies, the culture and group environment. Most of these students are under 18 and travel abroad for the first time.For the A2 activity, we kept the work plan for graduate students, so as to carry out a 150-day mobility in companies. Comparing to the year before, we reduced the number of mobilities from 8 to 6, since we will have a lower number of graduate students this year. For this activity, we kept the same partners, considering the good performance shown. However, and bearing in mind the previous experience, we believe it would be very helpful for them to have a teacher to do the monitoring and integration in this period of mobility. We realized that many students would even like to try this European experience, but they end up quitting as they are afraid of going alone and without the support of a teacher.In 2015 we started to organize the mobility for the 10th grade students to provide them a period of training in schools / training centers abroad, so as to prevent failure and dropout, and to increase their motivation to attend professional courses and their language learning. Both students and parents reacted very positively to the innovative proposal, which registered a high level of interest. So, for this A3 activity, we decided to keep the same number of mobilities (total of 30, divided into 3 flows). In what concerns the selection of partners, we took into account the targeted training areas in reference schools. Since these students are under 18, we included in each flow, a teacher who will accompany them throughout the whole period of mobility.For all the participating students, we will work on the validation of training modules according to the ECVET and provide support on the award of the Europass document.In what concerns the staff - A4 activity,  we foresee to organize 10 mobilities. We increased both the number of flows and partners to cover different training realities and to enhance enriching experiences for the participants, which will surely be useful for their professional performance in CIOR.In summary, the application proposal provides a total of 81 mobilities among 4 types of activity to be held during the year 2016/2017, according to the start and end dates of the project, 61 of these mobilities are for students, 11 mobilities are for accompanying teachers and 10 mobilities are planned for the professional development of Staff. In order to develop this project Cior has established 15 partnerships, in 9 EU country's. The criteria for the selection of participants will remain the same as those defined in previous projects, highlighting the inclusion of students with fewer opportunities or special needs.The dissemination activities planned for the GPS 4 project include a greater focus on the presentation of results outside our school, especially within other educational institutions.In order to reinforce the cultural and linguistic preparation of students, in addition to the actions developed in the training context, Cior established partnerships with local Youth Associations, which work in the area of citizenship and inclusion (Yupi).The Evaluation Plan provided for this project includes the overall assessment of its impact in what concerns the students and staff learning outcomes as well as the School pro-European projection provided by this project.
Zagraniczne praktyki zawodowe szansa lepszej pracy

The project reflects the strategy of internationalizing the Agricultural Complex of Schools in Namysłów and involves the 4-week foreign vocational training in 2017 for 97 students of the technical vocational school in 7 professions and also the staff training. From 01/05/2017 to 26/05/2017 there are 4 groups of students which are going to be trained and these are: 12 students in the profession of an IT specialist in the training center in Plymouth in the Great Britain, where 13 other students will undertake training in the profession of a photo technician in companies, 31 students of: the technical vocational school of the tourist service, hotel industry and nutrition technology will be placed for training in hotels, restaurants and travel agencies in Rimini, Italy, 20 students of nutrition technology in Malaga, Spain. 2 more groups in July: 9 students of the landscape architecture of the technical vocational school in the botanical garden of Malaga, and 12 students of agribusiness in August and September in agricultural farms of southern Hesse. In September 2016 the school headmaster together with the deputy and two teachers will undertake a job shadowing training in school of Dieburg, and in July next year 7 teachers of vocational subjects will undertake a two-week internship in hotels and restaurants of Malaga. Staff training is going to be a new undertaking to the school mobility program.According to the internationalizing strategy two new hosting organizations have been acquired:  TRIBEKA TRAINING LAB S.L. in Malaga and Landrat-Gruber-Schule in Dieburg. The cooperation with current hosting organization will be maintained:  Tellus of Plymouth with its branch in Rome, Sistema Tourismo of Rimini, Starkenburg Farmers Association in Darmstadt, Germany. The main goals of the project are: the development of skills and professional knowledge of students and staff and their ability to communicate in foreign languages and their personal development: increase in their responsibility, self-reliance, self-confidence, tolerance for other cultures and the ability to deal with difficult situations. The project is crucial for the learning and development process of students of technical vocational schools due to the fact that it gives them new skills and professional knowledge and it increases their mobility on the labor market. Future graduates are better prepared for work. The project is putting more emphasis on the European aspect of technical vocational education and encourages students in linking theory and practice, in better understanding of foreign cultures and customs, together with the development of language skills, especially with using professional language. The project is contributing to the mobility and the personal development of its participants, allowing them to know foreign cultures more adequately, without the threat of feeling alone in an unknown environment, establishing new contacts and friendships, coping with difficult situations and their increase in pride and self-esteem.Staff training increases their professional skills. The headmaster and the deputy will benefit from experience exchange and will try to implement organizational solutions to their school management to increase its overall performance.As a result of bonding the labor environment with the educational environment the project is enhancing the chances of employment for its future graduates on the European service market. The project is promoting the transparency and credibility of professional qualifications in Europe based on The European Credit Transfer System for Vocational Education and Training (ECVET).Care of the students will be supervised by the teachers from the Agricultural Schools Complex and the representatives of the partner organizations, as well as caregivers in individual enterprises. Teachers presence is crucial as they will provide comfort and safety for students, will help them in difficult situations, ease language barriers and verify their training outcome.Another result of the project is to increase students' skills in communicating in English, German,  Italian and Spanish languages, and the acquisition of independence and responsibility. Students will be prepared pedagogically, culturally and linguistically. The project participants will be provided with travel, insurance, accommodation and meals abroad, tickets for transport and pocket money. After completing the practice students will receive certificates confirming the acquisition of new competencies and Europass Mobility documents.The project contributes to the development of the industries in which future graduates will find employment. Long term benefits are primarily the acquisition by the participants with new experience, transferring new skills and solutions to Poland and the development of the European strategy of internationalizing the Agricultural Complex of Schools in Namysłów.

The opening-up to Europe and international level is at the heart of the 7 vocational and technical high schools listed below, forming a cluster in 5 big cities of the Bouches du Rhône County:

- BRISE LAMES in Martigues, European Sections in Sales, Commerce, Business Administration
 - Lycée des métiers, CELONY in Aix en Provence, European Section Commerce
 - Lycée des Métiers, CAUCADIS in Vitrolles
 - Lycée des métiers LE ROCHER in Salon
 - Lycée des Métiers CHARLOTTE GRAWITZ, lycées EDMOND ROSTAND, MARIE GASQUET, European Section in Sales, all in Marseille

More than 3000 students prepare diplomas from CAP (level 3) to BAC PRO (level 4) in various professional fields; vocational training and education’s core mission is to increase students employability, social inclusion by offering a teaching of quality in keeping with youth’s needs in a world of work in constant evolution, putting into perspective the strategic value of intercultural and multilingual communication as an asset in building tomorrow’s Europe

Relying on a significant Leonardo, Comenius, Erasmus projects experience over the past 10 years and in order to sustain the international strategy of the schools, 2 management staff members and 25 teachers, after analysing their needs, are involved in this project to develop their linguistics, sociolinguistics and teaching skills.
Therefore, this project is intended to:
- Foster skills development of 4 experienced DNL (non linguistic subject) teachers and extend the scope of cross-disciplinary teaching in the existing European sections
- Train 4 teachers to CLIL methods; enhance their linguistic skills in order to prepare them to the DNL certification enabling the schools to open new European classes in Bac Pro Health Care, Catering and hospitality
- Strengthen linguistic and teaching skills of 9 English teachers enabling them to adapt their learning strategies of a foreign language
- Improve language skills and cultural awareness of 8 teachers of professional and academic subjects in order to increase the involvement in the management of European projects and students ‘preparation for mobility
- Broaden and upgrade the knowledge of 2 management staff regarding innovative teaching methods and educational system focusing on students’ success and prevention of school failure

To achieve these goals, the 25  teachers will attend a one-week training course  in Portsmouth, UK,designed to meet their language level and needs; the 2 management staff will undertake a job shadowing for a week in Finland, a country whose educational system is at the-state-of-the-art in innovation and educational quality.
Prior to their mobility, beneficiaries will follow a preparation program and will report and document their progress in a continuous monitoring; a EUROPASS Mobility certificate will validate their experience and skills

 Management of this project build upon existing knowhow by all stakeholders in the 7 schools:
A steering committee, a specific assignment to a project coordinator and referent person in each school ensure the good working of the project and comply with the bill of specifications:
Yearly calendar, procedures guide for each group of mobility, evaluation and certification tools, project follow -up, dissemination plan allow an efficient management, information flow among all stakeholders.

Expected results and impact in the short to long run are:
- A significant linguistic progress of the beneficiaries
- New skills and knowledge to reinvest in students curriculum
- An increase of students performance
- An extended share of good practice and new digital and teaching tools with the education community
- Widening mobility opportunities through a large range of courses
- Broadening the educational offer of European sections with well trained teachers
- Acknowledgement of the quality of the projects implemented within the 7 schools by obtaining the Erasmus +mobility Charter
Mobilité des cadres de l'Académie de Versailles

1) Current situation 
The Academy of Versailles is France’s largest education local authority with 9% of the country’s school-children and students. A very contrasted academy with very wealthy and also very poor areas, it has 97 networks of schools classified under what is called Priority Education Networks.
Applications for Erasmus+ funding account for only 5% of the French funded projects, a percentage which is too low. Moreover, the French Ministry of Education insists that all the school-children should go on a school trip once or more during their school years. 

2) Themes and goals
The project has three goals : firstly learning difficulties, particularly for pupils in Priority Education Networks ;  secondly, the implementation of the Secondary School Reform ; thirdly, the development of new mobility projects for the pupils and the teachers. 
The project is inspired by a circular note dated February 3, 2016 on the vocational training periods of inspectors and head teachers during their probation period. It is also in compliance with the three main lines of the academic project : 1. School success for everyone everywhere 2. Learning and acting in the 21st century world 3.Investing in staff training.

3) Participants and activities
27 head teachers and inspectors are staying one week in a European country where they are involved in job shadowing or structured courses. There, they will have the opportunity to find out about some European education systems. They will also exchange best practices and learn how to handle pupils' learning difficulties and implement the 2016 French secondary school reforms. Their applications were studied with various criteria. They had preferably to work in a Priority Education Network and have a view of the dissemination plan they would develop afterwards. Then, through this project, our staff members will get an expertise which will make the best practices in the educational field easier to develop.

4) Results
The activities carried out during the mobility period will improve the personal, cultural, intercultural and professional competences of the staff.  The staff will also develop their professional motivation and their capacity to support/coordinate future European mobility projects in their schools.

5) Impacts and long-term profits 
The project will have a sizeable impact on the participants’ competences and professional practices. It will also strongly impact the schools, the inspection and the academy. In the long run, pupils living in the poorest areas should get the benefits as the applicants will come back with new  practices to handle learning difficulties and they will be more willing and able to develop the pupils’ mobility.
Last but not least, after meeting and working with Europeans peers, our staff will be in a position to find new school-to-school partnerships  and the whole process will be a bonus to the educational cooperation in the academy.
Nauczyciel też uczy się przez całe życie.

The applying organization in the project is Zespół Szkół im. Juliana Tuwima, which provides qualifications in the Hotel and Tourism vocational area. The project participants are teachers from the school.

During the planning stage of the project, in order to investigate the needs of the school, but also for the project to meet the teachers’ needs, a questionnaire was distributed among the teachers to show the direction and type of planned courses. The legitimacy of such actions has been confirmed by the number of school staff, who have expressed a desire to join the project, making a group of participants up to 26 people. In addition, the project assumptions are dictated by the policies of the Ministry of Education and meet the horizontal and structural priorities.
The main objective of this project is to prepare teachers to participate in foreign trainings through participation in courses which improve language skills or allow to learn new languages in striving of multilingualism. It is planned to organize language courses in four countries (Great Britain, Spain, Italy and Germany). In addition, foreign language teachers will take part teacher training. These courses and observations will help to improve the quality of teaching at Polish school, because on the basis of received information it is advisable to introduce elements of a foreign language during vocational subjects and humanities (elements of CLIL), as well as using the latest teaching methods and techniques of a foreign language observed abroad. The project will also contribute to broaden the horizons and worldview, to skill sharing with teachers from other European countries and promoting the concept of lifelong learning. Teachers will be able to familiarize themselves with various education systems in Europe. The next objective will be to establish new international contacts and increase teachers’ involvement in the development of new application forms of European Programme, as well as sharing their experience from a language course abroad with students going for training abroad.
In order to prepare for departure, each participant will have the opportunity to take part in the cultural preparation and short language course in Poland. When it comes to language courses organized abroad, they will be prepared and carried out by an organization Tellus Education Group from the UK which has extensive experience on the international market in organizing language, methodical and professional courses, not only in England, but also in Italy, Spain, Germany and Poland. The project activities have been planned so as not to interfere with the work schedule at school, so the dates within which the courses will be organized include a period of winter and summer vacations. During the project essential tests will be carried out to assess the level of participants’ language skills (before and after the course), as well as other forms of assessing their progress in order to achieve the best results.
All activities undertaken during the project implementation will be monitored by the project coordinators. There are several methods that will be used in order to obtain it: direct observation of the language courses, current interviews with project participants and an analysis of information posted on websites, facebook and publications connected with the dissemination process. In order to assess the activities and results of the project an analysis of the results of the survey conducted among the participants after the course completion will be interpreted. The project itself and its results will form the foundation for future projects offering further training for staff working in the school.
Project activities will bring numerous additional benefits, not only for all participants, but also the whole teaching staff, such as increase in the teachers’ mobility, improving language skills, the development of tolerance and openness to other cultures, overcoming prejudice and stereotypes, familiarizing with work in different linguistic and cultural conditions, as well as the ability to work in an international environment. In addition, it will enrich the educational offer of the school. Finally, in the future a number of people participating in dissemination activities of project results will be able to use it indirectly.
education unlimited - rely on partners in Europe

The project “"education unlimited - rely on partners in Europe", abbreviated "eu-rope", offers students on full-time BTEC-Courses as well as trainees in the dual system the chance to gather work experience in their future profession by strengthening their intercultural competencies and developing of personality at the same time. For this purpose participating students do a four-to-six-week work placement in companies or institutions of their professional field.
The applying vocational college “Berufskolleg Deutzer Freiheit”, Cologne, as well as its cooperating partner “Berufskolleg St. Nikolaus-Stift”, Zülpich, have had long-term experience with sending and receiving young people. Predominantly we have been focusing on stimulating our participants’ independance, including students with handicaps and special needs. Quite a number of trainees profit from the international contacts of their training company when finding a suitable work placement. Furthermore the two vocational colleges have been cultivating a wide network of various national and international partners. 
For the current application it has been projected to send abroad about 100 participants doing an initial vocational training. 
Additionally the project “eu-rope” is aimed at those who are responsible in the field of vocational training. They get the chance of upgrading their competencies and sharing their educational “best practice ideas and experience” with partners abroad.
This way the project has been appreciated by many national and international network-partners of the above-mentioned vocational colleges. It does not only focus on upgrading the intercultural competencies of its participants but all the same on the personal and professional profit from a work placement abroad.
Arbeiten, Leben und Lernen für Europas Zukunft III

The project "Arbeiten, Leben und Lernen für Europas Zukunft III" (ALLEZ III) is focused on preparing students and apprentices of Max-Born vocational college as well as possible for a successful future (working) life in the European context.
To reach this aim, students are offered four-week internships in various European countries.
Looking back on several years of experience with international co-operations, this project again offers the opportunity to get an insight into life and work abroad to interested students and apprentices of all fields of education and trades.
Interested students can apply to the project’s management team for a placement in the country of their choice. The intermediate partners will then find a placement within the respective vocational field. Thus, it is ensured that students can profit from their experience not only regarding their linguistic and professional skills, but also in the future, for example in applications when they can prove their international experience using the Europass. 
As visitors abroad, the learners are representatives not only of the Max-Born vocational college, but also of the culture of the Ruhrmetropolis and Germany. Hence, they play an important role as mediators between the cultures.

The project target group at Sedus Stoll AG comprises trainees in the dual system (vocational school + training at the company). For our company, it is particularly important that the trainees are able to acquire technical, social, intercultural and linguistic competencies already during the apprenticeship. From our previous experience we have learned that a foreign assignment of trainees creates a significant added value to the apprenticeship.

Sedus Stoll is submitting the fourth application within the framework of european mobility programs Erasmus+. With our application we wish to continue offering the opportunity and experience of an internship abroad to our trainees. In their first year of training, the participants were able to gain practical experience which will allow them to distinguish between the various international working environments.

Besides an independent and responsible work, the main focus of the internship is on a self-confident conduct towards our domestic and foreign customers. This not only requires good communication and rhetorical skills in the German language but also an excellent command of foreign languages. In addition to a high level of mobility and flexibility of our employees, Sedus places great emphasis on the ability to act in an international context. This competence is mandatory for an export-oriented company. 
Furthermore, the project strengthens our image as a company with attractive career opportunities and thus leads to a higher number of well-qualified applications. In this regard, we have already noticed on vocational training fairs that potential candidates are increasingly asking for the possibility of an internship abroad. 
The deployments shall also serve to establish contacts with foreign business partners and increasingly intensify and expand relations.

In addition, the project will ensure transparency and acknowledgement of the skills and abilities acquired by the participants which is confirmed by the Europass Mobility.

The project is intended to promote the European idea in the school, i.e. the development of student and staff mobility. In addition to the cross-cultural and professional experiences, the students will develop their personality . The aim of the project is to promote mobility across national borders, to give the students confidence in their abilities, and exchange practical professional as well as language skills.
Together with the ADC College in London, the participating teachers of Nelly-Puetz-vocational college have developed a three-week programme. The participants first attend a professional-oriented language course and then do an internship in London companies and institutions. These experiences are now to be employed in other European countries. Consequently, the range of Nelly-Puetz-vocational college can be expanded by a project that supports the preparation of students for an increasingly internationalized and European work environment and allows space for personal development and a strengthening of European values such as acceptance and integration.
The project involves students of the Dual System in the hotel, restaurant and hair-dressers’ trades, care workers as well as child care professionals.
The project combines a one-week language course with a two-week internship in different institutions and companies in England, Ireland, Spain and Malta.
The preceding language course will improve language skills of the students to the effect that they will get along well in everyday life, but especially during their internship abroad.
The main aim of the internship is to provide first international experiences for students. These will be very valuable for their professional future either with international guests or customers in Germany or abroad.
Other aims for all groups are, of course, the improvement of the communicative competence and the acquisition of key skills, such as social and intercultural competence.
The students create an illustrated blog in the form of a travel diary about their stay, their personal and professional experiences.

The project WPA IV(‘Work placements abroad IV‘) is a follow-up project to the projects ‚WPA’ that commenced in 2011 to WPAIII.
 
The project is applied and coordinated by the ‚Berufskolleg West der Stadt Essen‘, a vocational college in Essen in the German federal state of North Rhine Westphalia, Germany. The European partners are either vocational colleges or institutions working as mediating partners or companies situated in either Finland, France or the UK.
 
WPA IV focusses on mobilities of students in initial vocational training on ISCED level 4 education in courses related to metal technology and engineering (5 mobilities) as well as on mobilities of educational staff and, where applicable, in-company instructors from partners in initial dual vocational training (14 mobilities).
Two teachers from the field of chemistry and plastic technology will follow teaching/training assignments and teach abroad in the target language (UK, NL) at a VET school. 
Twelve educational staff members from either the field of mechanical engineering or safety and security or teachers working in schedule planning and with substitution schedules will do a 2-days lasting job shadowing/observation period abroad in an enterprise or VET organisation (FIN, UK, FR).
At the time of the mobility the students will be in their second year of training and  realize a 4-weeks work placement in a company abroad in the field of metalwork and mechanical engineering. (FIN, UK) 

The main sustainable objectives of this project are 

A. for the institution Berufskolleg West
• consolidation of its internationalization strategy thereby enhancing its competitiveness as a vocational college in the region
• encouraging the learning and working within a European network of companies and educational institutions and those in the l
  labour market in order to strengthen the region as a business location and enhancing its competitiveness 
• effecting quality objectives in vocational training by implementing mobilities and its outcomes into curricula and in-company 
   training
• quality development of work placements abroad with regard to the quality commitment in learning agreements and ECVET t
  transparency instruments.

B. for the educational staff
• providing training personnel of the vocational college and instructors in companies adequate instruments for the encouragement 
   of individuals to pursue work placements abroad 
• development educational personnel’s competencies with regard to their teaching objectives and functions within the vocational 
   college
• enhancing project management skills for realizing work placements abroad

C. for the students
• sustainable development of social and personal skills or our students including flexibility, communications skills, team spirit and 
   tolerance through vocational work experience within a different cultural context
• sustainable development of apprentices’ technical skills by taking into consideration both the level of training and individual r
   requirements and hereby increasing their opportunities on the labour market
• development the students’ language skills, primarily the knowledge of English as lingua franca.

In the long run WPA IV contributes to the institutions’ reputation and impact within the region plus the students’ competitiveness on the European labour market.

Our project "Voith goes Europe – Building Skills" is a project we are going to apply to for 16 commercial trainees. The trainees are technically, practically excellence trained by us in Heidenheim, and the theoretical content by the training school. The increased international focus of the company is due to our combined dual training. To stay abroad should be an integral component within the training for motivated, dedicated and high performing trainees in their second and third year which will pave their way after a successful completion of the training. Very important to us is, in addition to the intensive development of foreign language skills the aspect of personality development and the development of intercultural competence.
The stay abroad lasts for four weeks. In the first week, the trainees take part in an intensive English language course, this is followed by a three-week internship. The trainees are housed during their stay with a host family. Before the trip the participating students are thoroughly prepared for their stay. All organizational aspects such as travel planning, insurance and what to do in an emergency case, as well as intercultural topics will be reviewed with an English coach.
We work closely with the project partner organization Tellus Group in the UK. The partner organization takes over the placement of practical operations and the homestay.
The experiences we have gained in  previous projects (Leonardo da Vinci and Erasmus+) with foreign assignments has proved to us how valuable and lasting these stays are for our trainees. After the return of the trainees, their personal development, especially self-esteem and independence was noticeably improved. After completion of training the opportunity to be offered a contract has visibly risen. It now shows that the posts offered to our commercial trainees are of a higher quality. The demand from our departments for employees with an international and highly qualified education could be partly fulfilled through this project.
Education Train - GeNo-Media, Ge-No Bau, Goe-Move, GeNo-Economy, Job-Shadowing

Behind the Education Train more smaller projects of GFT-Erasmus e.V.. All this of vocational education and trainings. They aim internationalization. So far we were able to establish networking and cooperation to Sweden, Norway, Italy, Spain, Ireland, England, Finland, Poland, Croatia and Hungary.
A small project is the cooperation to Norway. It says GeNo-media . The cooperation provides that Norwegian trainees come to Germany and learn printing techniques in three weeks. The BBS II Göttingen is a specialist in this area and has an excellent Department of printing technology. In return, German apprentices go to Norway, where they learn audio and video technology. In sound and video technology can unfortunately only be breathe pure. This topic is very extensive and is taught in Norway one year. Both partners thereby increase their competence and quality of education. This is the Norwegians but also the Germans for good.
Move-Göttingen is our biggest project. It exchanges trainees, trainers and education staff. The length of stay in Germany or an EU country move from four weeks to six months. The cooperation exists between businesses, schools and universities from Germany and the EU. The German University of Göttingen sends trainees in the field of natural sciences in universities or hospitals of Europe. A similar approach companies from Südniedersachsen. They aim trainers, trainees and training staff to educate and train. Here, the participants will get to know other methods. In addition, this promotes key qualifications in social skills, language skills and intercultural competence. This is not a one-way street. This is currently only in professional training for biology, chemistry or physics laboratory that. This apprenticeship does not exist in other EU countries. The finished laboratory technicians from Germany therefore have a large labor market. You will be gladly taken as professionals in EU countries. Initial experience this, we have made in Sweden. So it happened that a student is gone after their examination in January 2015. Sweden to the University of Uppsala. She now works at the Institute, where she had her internship. We see this as a great success.
Green School is a new project also between several scientific schools in Europe. The participants meet once a year in small groups and work together. There are also individual trainees and training staff to be replaced. So the project is to come and stay in each school at the same level. It is constantly being developed and expanded. A goal should be to find cheap drugs for developing countries based on natural ingredients. These can then, for example, are produced in countries with little effort itself. There's a little bit of thought "medicines for all" behind it. Each participating country has special herbs that grow only there. These herbs are cultivated in gardens themselves, researched and studied. The ingredients of the herbs to be analyzed.
